docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration announced today that Medicare payments to doctors would be cut 4.4 percent next year, after a 5.4 percent cut this year. Federal officials predicted that doctors would, as a result, be less willing to accept new Medicare patients. If the cuts are not reversed, Congress and the administration will face the wrath of two politically potent constituencies, elderly voters and doctors who care for the elderly. But administration officials are desperately trying to control federal health costs, which they see as a major factor that contributes to federal budget deficits.

headline.main: Medicare to Cut Payments To Doctors 4.4% Next Year

docs.abstract: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services administrator Thomas Scully, following cut of 5.4 percent this year, announces 4.4 percent cut in Medicare payments to doctors in 2003; Health and Human Services Department officials predict doctors, as result, will be less willing to accept new Medicare patients; outraged doctors fault Congress and Bush administration for failing to avert cuts, which will begin on March 1 (M)
docs.snippet: The Bush administration announced today that Medicare payments to doctors would be cut 4.4 percent next year, after a 5.4 percent cut this year. Federal officials predicted that doctors would, as a result, be less willing to accept new Medicare...

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: CENTERS FOR MEDICARE AND MEDICAID SERVICES

docs.lead_paragraph: The German chemical and drug maker Bayer said yesterday that it had reached a preliminary settlement with the United States attorney in Massachusetts on an investigation of the prices it charged state and federal health insurers for drugs from 1995 to 2000. Bayer said the final terms had not been determined but it had set aside $257.2 million to cover the cost. The Bayer Corporation, the company's unit in the United States, was the subject of a joint civil and criminal investigation concerning allegations that it improperly underpaid rebates, particularly involving the Medicaid program. Victor Homola (NYT)

headline.main: BAYER SETTLES GOVERNMENT INQUIRY ON OVERCHARGING

docs.abstract: German chemical and drug maker Bayer reaches preliminary settlement with United States attorney in Massachusetts on investigation of prices it charged state and federal health insurers and Medicaid for drugs from 1995 to 2000; sets aside $257.2 million to cover cost (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority accused the transit workers' union yesterday of ''spinning'' the amount of wage and benefit increases in the new labor agreement and argued that the increases were less than union officials say. Gary J. Dellaverson, the M.T.A.'s chief negotiator, said the authority would pay an additional $448 million in wages and benefits over the life of the three-year contract. That is considerably less than the $600 million estimated by officials from Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union.

headline.main: M.T.A. Says Union Is Exaggerating Wage and Benefit Gains

docs.abstract: Metropolitan Transportation Authority accuses Transit Workers Union Local 100 of exaggerating amount of wage and benefit increases in new labor agreement in effort to boast about success of labor negotiations (M)
docs.snippet: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority accused the transit workers' union yesterday of ''spinning'' the amount of wage and benefit increases in the new labor agreement and argued that the increases were less than union officials say.    Gary J....

docs.lead_paragraph: In the Hollywood film ''About Schmidt,'' Jack Nicholson's character tries to help a little African boy named Ndugu by sponsoring him for $22 a month. Ndugu does not speak a word in the movie. He just looks out from a photograph with big eyes and a serious face. Mr. Nicholson, playing Warren Schmidt, a newly retired insurance actuary who struggles with long-submerged feelings, pours out his heart to the destitute child in long letters that he sends to a remote village in a faraway place.

headline.main: Via Hollywood, a Glimpse of African Poverty

docs.abstract: Movie About Schmidt, starring Jack Nicholson, includes character Ndugu, young African boy Nicholson's character is sponsoring; film's director and co-screenwriter Alexander Payne says he sought help from Childreach of Warwick, RI, in finding real child on which to base Ndugu, who is seen only in photograph; that child is 6-year-old Abdallah Mtulu of Lugongole, Tanzania; Abdallah's parents gave permission for his photo to be used in film, but they received no money from producers; photo; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Columbia University agreed yesterday to pay $5.1 million to settle a civil complaint that it billed the state Medicaid program for obstetrical services that Columbia doctors did not provide. The settlement resolves a lawsuit brought by federal prosecutors accusing the university of billing the government for birthing services that were actually performed by midwives, residents and other doctors who were not eligible for Medicaid reimbursement.

headline.main: Columbia Settles Suit on Billing Practices

docs.abstract: Columbia University agrees to pay $5.1 million to settle civil suit alleging it billed New York Medicaid program for birthing services that Columbia doctors did not provide; midwives, residents and other doctors at Allen Pavilion, community hospital operated by New York Presbyterian Hospital and Columbia University, performed services; Columbia admits to no wrong-doing in settlement (M)
docs.snippet: Columbia University agreed yesterday to pay $5.1 million to settle a civil complaint that it billed the state Medicaid program for obstetrical services that Columbia doctors did not provide.    The settlement resolves a lawsuit brought by federal...

docs.lead_paragraph: The problems at Tenet Healthcare intensified yesterday when federal law enforcement officials served search warrants and sealed the offices of two top executives at a California hospital owned by the company. Officials from the United States attorney's office in San Diego issued warrants to search the records of the hospital's chief executive, Barry Weinbaum, and its director of business development, Mina Nazaryan, seeking information about various arrangements between the hospital, Alvarado Hospital Medical Center in San Diego, and its doctors.

headline.main: More Scrutiny For Big Chain Of Hospitals

docs.abstract: Problems at Tenet Healthcare intensify when federal law enforcement officials serve search warrants and seal offices of chief executive Barry Weinbaum and business director Mina Nazaryan at Alvarado Hospital Medical Center in San Diego, which is owned by Tenet; search warrants says officials are being investigating possible violations of laws that prohibit doctors from being paid to refer patients; warrants seek records on recruiting of doctors by hospital as well as relocation and consulting agreements between hospital and doctors from 1995 to present; officials also plan to review way that some of executives of hospital are paid; under federal anti-kickback laws for Medicare and Medicaid, hospitals are forbidden to pay or otherwise induce doctors to send them patients; Tenet denies it violated any anti-kickback rules, and says no charges have been filed against company or hospital executives; Dr Bernard A Michlin, one of doctors whose admission and referral records are sought in search warrants, says he has no idea what federal investigation is all about (M)
docs.snippet: The problems at Tenet Healthcare intensified yesterday when federal law enforcement officials served search warrants and sealed the offices of two top executives at a California hospital owned by the company.     Officials from the United States...

byline.original: By REED ABELSON with ANDREW POLLACK

docs.lead_paragraph: The percentage of babies born prematurely in the United States reached a 20-year high last year, driven by an increase in twins and triplets. The government also found a rise in prenatal care and a drop in smoking during pregnancy. Births to teenagers fell for the 10th year in a row, with abortions declining, too. At the same time, births to women in their 30's and 40's continued to climb steadily, according to an annual review of birth statistics released today. Over all, 4,025,933 babies were born in the United States in 2001, a small drop from 2000.

headline.main: Surge in Multiple Births Produces Record in Premature Babies

docs.abstract: Percentage of babies born prematurely in United States reaches 20-year high last year, nearly 12 percent, driven by increase in twins and triplets; government also finds rise in prenatal care and drop in smoking during pregnancy; births to teenagers fell for 10th year in row (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HCA, the nation's largest for-profit hospital chain, announced a settlement with the Justice Department of more than $880 million today to end a nine-year investigation into allegations of fraud. The settlement, which requires formal approval by the Justice Department and courts, would raise the amount of civil fines and criminal penalties HCA has paid the government in recent years to $1.7 billion.
docs.abstract: HCA, nation's largest for-profit hospital chain, announces settlement with Justice Department of more than $880 million to end nine-year investigation into allegations of fraud; settlement will raise amount of civil fines and criminal penalties HCA has paid to government in recent years to $1.7 billion; whistle-blowers charged HCA filed false claims and paid kickbacks to doctors so they would refer Medicare and Medicaid patients to its operations (S)
docs.snippet: HCA, the nation's largest for-profit hospital chain, announced a settlement with the Justice Department of more than $880 million today to end a nine-year investigation into allegations of fraud.     The settlement, which requires formal approval by...

docs.lead_paragraph: In a brief speech with a main theme of compromise, Gov. John G. Rowland urged a joint meeting of the state's General Assembly to adopt his plan to fill a $500 million hole in the current state budget before next year's legislative session begins on Jan. 8. Mr. Rowland's formal remarks to the Legislature -- all of nine minutes' worth -- opened a special session he convened to force Democrats who control both houses to immediately balance Connecticut's current $13.2 billion budget. Though the remarks did not reflect any new demands or changes to his proposed mixture of tax increases, spending cuts and wage and benefit concessions from 50,000 unionized state employees, the governor put on a noticeably gentler face than he had during the past week.

headline.main: Rowland Urges Compromise to Repair Budget

docs.abstract: Connecticut Gov John G Rowland urges General Assembly to adopt his plan to close $500 million hole in state budget before next year's legislative session opens in January; proposal combines tax increases, spending cuts and wage and benefit concessions from unionized state employees; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Deliveries that send new mothers home from the hospital after one night do not seriously endanger newborns despite the many state laws that restrict the practice, a study to be published on Thursday says. Regardless of whether they had long or short stays, infants were later sent to the emergency room or readmitted to the hospital at the same rate, according to the study, by researchers from the Harvard Medical School.

headline.main: Newborn's One-Night Stay Said to Pose No Danger

docs.abstract: Harvard Medical School study finds that deliveries that send new mothers home from hospital after one night do not seriously endanger newborns despite the many state laws that restrict practice; study shows that regardless of whether they had long or short stays, infants were later sent to emergency room or readmitted to hospital at same rate (M)
